title-group.article-title: Free vibration analysis of three-parameter functionally graded material sandwich plates resting on Pasternak foundations

article-meta.aff: 1Young Researchers Club, Kermanshah Branch, Islamic Azad University, Kermanshah, Iran
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Razi University, Kermanshah, Iran
3Young Researchers Club, Islamic Azad University, Tehran Markaz- Branch, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Saeed Kamarian, 6718997551, kermanshah, Islamic Republic of Iran. Email: kamarian.saeed@yahoo.com.

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Based on the three-dimensional elasticity theory, this paper focuses on the free vibration characteristics of functionally graded sandwich rectangular plates resting on Pasternak foundations. The two-constituent functionally graded plate consists of ceramic and metal. These constituents are graded through the thickness according to a three-parameter power-law distribution. The benefit of using the considered power-law distribution is to illustrate and present useful results arising from symmetric, asymmetric and classic profiles. In this research work, a detailed parametric study is carried out to highlight the influences of different profiles of fiber volume fraction, three parameters of power-law distribution and two-parameter elastic foundation modulus on the vibration characteristics of the functionally graded sandwich plates.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Sandwich structures are used in a variety of engineering applications including aircraft, construction and transportation where strong, stiff and light structures are required. The advantages of these structures are that it provides high specific stiffness and strength for a low-weight consideration. Due to the mismatch of stiffness properties between the face sheets and the core, sandwich plates are susceptible to face sheet/core debonding, which is a major problem in sandwich construction, especially under impact loading [1]. To increase the resistance of sandwich plates to this type of failure, the concept of a functionally graded material (FGM) is being actively explored in sandwich structure design. FGMs are achieved by gradually changing the composition of the constituent materials along one (or more) direction(s), usually in the thickness direction, to obtain smooth variation of material properties and optimum response to externally applied loading. Various material profiles through the functionally graded plate thickness can be illustrated by using three-parameter power-law distribution. In fact, by using this power-law distribution, it is possible to study the influence of the different kinds of material profiles. Recently, Viola and Tornabene [2] used three-parameter power-law distribution to study the dynamic behavior of functionally graded parabolic panels of revolution.

Plates resting on elastic foundations with different shapes, size and thickness variations and boundary conditions have been the subject of numerous investigations and those play an important role in aerospace, marine, civil, mechanical, electronic and nuclear engineering problems. The Pasternak model (also referred to as the two-parameter model) was widely used to describe the mechanical behavior of the foundation, in which the well-known Winkler model is a special case [3,4]. Batra and Jin [5] used the first order shear deformation theory (FSDT) coupled with the finite element method to study free vibrations of a functionally graded anisotropic rectangular plate. Malekzadeh [6] studied three-dimensional free vibrations analyses of thick functionally graded plates on elastic foundations by using Differential Quadratic (DQ) method.

Though there are research works reported on general sandwich structures, very little work has been done to consider the vibration behavior of FGM sandwich (FGSW) structures [7,8]. Li et al. [9] studied free vibrations of FGSW rectangular plates with simply supported and clamped edges. Zenkour [10,11] presented a two-dimensional solution to study the bending, buckling and free vibration of simply supported FG ceramic–metal sandwich plates. Recently, Xiang et al. [12] analyzed the free vibration of sandwich plate with functionally graded face and homogeneous core using meshless global collocation method on the thin plate spline radial basis function and nth-order shear deformation theory.

In order to distinguish the present work from the above pertinent literature, effect of functionally graded face sheets and two-parameter elastic foundation modulus on free vibration of FGSW rectangular plates is investigated. The fiber-reinforced composite material studied in the present work consists of alumina (ceramic) fibers embedded in aluminum (metal) matrix with the fiber volume fraction graded according to a three-parameter power-law distribution through thickness. Frequency parameters are obtained by using numerical technique termed the generalized differential quadrature method (GDQM), which leads to a generalized eigenvalue problem. The differential quadrature method (DQM) is found to be a simple and efficient numerical technique for solving partial differential equations as reported by Bellman et al. [13]. The mathematical fundamental and recent development of GDQ method as well as its major applications in engineering is discussed in detail in Ref. [14].

sec.title: FGSW material properties
sec.p:
Consider a thick FGSW plate rested on two-parameter elastic foundations as shown in Figure 1. A Cartesian coordinate system (x, y, z) is used to label the material point of the plate in the unstressed reference configuration. The lower surface of plate is continuously in contact with an elastic medium that acts as an elastic foundation represented by the Winkler/Pasternak model with stiffness kw and shear stiffness kg. Figure 1.
A functionally graded sandwich (FGSW) plate resting on elastic foundation.

The plate has continuous grading of fiber reinforcement through thickness. h, hc and hf are the thickness of plate, core and face sheets, respectively, and the plate is assumed to be symmetric with respect to its mid-plane z=0.

The Young’s modulus E(z), Poisson’s ratio ν(z) and mass density ρ(z) of the FGSW plate can be expressed as: (1)E(z)=EcVc+EmVmρ(z)=ρcVc+ρmVmν(z)=vcVc+vmVm Where ρm,Em,υm,Vm and ρc,Ec,υc,Vc represent mass density, Young’s modulus, Poisson’s ratio and volume fraction of the metal and ceramic constituent materials, respectively. In the present work, the fiber volume fraction of FGSW plate is assumed as follows: (2)Vc(z)={1-[(z+h/h22hf)+b(1-z+h/h22hf)c]p,-h2≤z≤-h2+hf0,-h2+hf≤z≤h2-hf1-[(h/h22-zhf)+b(1-h/h22-zhf)c]p,h2-hf≤z≤h2 where the power-law index p (0≤p≤∞) and the parameters b, c dictate the fiber variation profile through the FGSW plate thickness. According to the relation (2), the core of FGSW plate and the inner surfaces of the sheets are metal rich, whereas the outer surfaces of the sheets can be metal rich, ceramic rich or made of a mixture of the two constituents. The through-thickness variations of Young's modulus of FGSW plate for some profiles are illustrated in Figure 2. The relevant material properties for the constituent materials are as follows [12,15]: Ec=380Gp a,ρc=3800kg/m3,υc=0.3,Em=70Gpa,υm=0.3,ρm=2707kg/m3 In Figure 2(a), the classical Young's modulus profiles are presented as special cases of the general distribution laws (2) by setting b=0, which has been recently considered for analysis of a FGSW rectangular plate by Xiang et al. [12]. In Figures 2(b) and 2(c), by setting b = 1, c = 2 and b = 1, c = 4 symmetric and asymmetric profiles respect to the mid-planes of the sheets (ζ=0) are obtained respectively. In Figure 2(d), Young's modulus profile for the different values of parameter c is shown by considering p=1 in which Young's modulus profile along z direction becomes asymmetric with increasing parameter c. Also, in this figure, Young's modulus on the inner and outer surfaces of sheets for the different values of parameter c is the same. Figure 2.
Variation of the Young's modulus through the thickness in the functionally graded sandwich (FGSW) plate. (a) b=0, (b) b=1,c=2, (c) b=1,c=4 and (d) b=1,p=1.

sec.title: The basic formulation
sec.p: The constitutive relations for the kth layer of the FGSW plate can be written as follows: (3){σxσyσzτzyτxzτxy}=[C11C12C13000C12C22C23000C13C23C33000000C44000000C55000000C66]{ɛxɛyɛzγzyγxzγxy} where coefficients cij are given in Appendix 1. In the absence of body forces, the governing equations are as follows: (4)∂σx∂x+∂τxy∂y+∂τxz∂z=ρ∂2u∂t2 (4)∂τxy∂x+∂σy∂y+∂τyz∂z=ρ∂2v∂t2∂τxz∂x+∂τyz∂y+∂σz∂z=ρ∂2w∂t2 strain-displacement relations are expressed as: (5)ɛz=∂w∂z ɛy=∂v∂y ɛx=∂u∂x.γxy=∂v∂x+∂u∂yγxz=∂w∂x+∂u∂z γyz=∂v∂z+∂w∂y where u,v,w are displacement components along the x, y and z axes, respectively. Upon substitution of equation (5) into equation (3) and then into equation (4), the following equations of motion as matrix form are obtained in terms of displacement components: (6)[L1xL1yL1zL2xL2yL2zL3xL3yL3z]{uvw}={ρu··ρv··ρw··} where coefficients Lij are given in Appendix 2. For a simply supported rectangular plate, the boundary conditions can be expressed on the x-constant as well as y-constant edges as: (7)u,x=v=w=0, u=v,y=w=0
Moreover, for the lower and upper surfaces of the plate, it can be written [6]: (8)τzx=τzy=0 and σz=kww-kg(∂2w∂x2+∂2w∂y2) atz=-h2σz=τzx=τzy=0 atz=h2

Using the method of separation of variables, it is possible to seek solutions that are harmonic in time and their frequency is ω. The displacements can be written as follows: (9)u=∑m=1∝∑n=1∝U(z)cos(βmx)sin(pny)eiωtv=∑m=1∝∑n=1∝V(z)sin(βmx)cos(pny)eiωtw=∑m=1∝∑n=1∝W(z)sin(βmx)sin(pny)eiωt where βm=mπL2(m=1,2,…) and pn=nπL1(n=1,2,…), m and n are wave numbers along x and y directions respectively. Inserting these displacement components into the equations of motion (6), one obtains a set of coupled differential equations with variable coefficients. (10)-C11βm2U-C12βmpnV+C13βm∂W∂z-pn2C66U-C66βmpnV+∂C55∂zβmW+C55βm∂W∂z+∂C55∂z∂U∂z+C55∂2U∂z2=-ρω2U-C66βmpnU-C66βm2V-C12βmpnU-C22pn2V+C23pn∂2W∂z+∂C44∂z∂V∂z+C44∂2V∂z2+∂C44∂zpnW+C44pn∂W∂z=-ρω2V-C55βm2W-C55βm∂U∂z-C44pn∂V∂z-C44pn2W-∂C13∂zβmU-C13βm∂U∂z-∂C23∂zpnV-C23pn∂V∂z+∂C33∂z∂W∂z+C33∂2W∂z2=-ρω2W

A semi–analytical procedure with the aid of DQ technique was recently developed [16]. According to the principle of this method, the nth-order partial derivative of a continuous function f(x, z) with respect to x at a given point xi can be approximated by a weighted linear summation of all the functional values along the descretized domain of x. If N discrete points are sampled in the domain of x, the nth-order partial derivative should be (11)∂fn(xi,z)∂xn=∑k=1Nciknf(xik,z), i=1,2,…,N, n=1,2,N-1 Where cijn are the weighting coefficients relating the nth derivative to the functional values at xi and N is the number of sampling points.

sec.title: Numerical and results
sec.p:
To verify the proficiency of presented method and three-parameter model for volume fraction of FGM materials, several numerical examples are carried out for comparisons. As a first example, the convergence and accuracy of the method is investigated in evaluating the first four natural frequency parameters of the FG moderately thick plates. The results are prepared for different values of the DQ grid points in Table 1. As noticed, fast rate of convergence of the GDQM is evident and it is founded that only 13 DQ grid in the thickness direction can yield accurate results for a graded plate. Also, one can see that excellent agreement exist between the results of this method and those of 2D higher order theory of Matsunaga [17]. Table 1.
Convergence behavior and accuracy of the first four non-dimensional natural frequencies (Ω=ωhρc/Ec) of a simply supported FG plate against the number of DQ grid points (h/L1 = 0.5).
Mode (n,m)
P (1,0) (1,1) (2,0) (1,2)

N = 13 0.357754 0.599487 0.958751 1.103656
N = 20 0.357758 0.599494 0.958764 1.103674
[6] 0.3577 0.5995 0.9587 1.1037
[17] 0.3579 0.5997 0.9591 1.1040
10 N = 9 0.328012 0.541517 0.852797 0.978336
N = 13 0.331127 0.545802 0.858398 0.984311
N = 20 0.331146 0.545833 0.858445 0.984365
[6] 0.3311 0.5458 0.8584 0.9843
[17] 0.3313 0.546 0.8588 0.9847
DQ: Differential Quadratic; FG: functionally graded.

For further verification of the results of new three-parameter model, by setting b = 0 in relation (2), the non-dimensional fundamental frequencies for the simply supported square sandwich plate with classic functionally graded face and homogeneous soft-core are listed in Table 2. The ceramic volume fraction in this case is as shown in Figure 2(a). It is seen that the present results agree well with those obtained through three-dimensional Ritz solution by Li et al. [9] as well as meshless global collocation method by Xiang et al. [12]. Table 2.
Comparison of none dimensional fundamental frequency (ω*=ω(L12h)ρ0/ρ0E0E0) for the simply supported square sandwich plates with classic functionally graded material (FGM) faces (b=0,Kg=Kw=0,h/L1=0.1,ρ0=1kg/m3,E0=1GPa).

As another example, to verify the results for plates on elastic foundation, the first three natural frequency parameters of isotropic thick plate with two different values of thickness-to-length ratios and different values of Winkler elastic coefficient are presented in Table 3. They are compared with those of the 2D higher order theory of Matsunaga [17] and three-dimensional Ritz solution of Zhou et al. [18]. High accuracy of the method can be seen. The parameters b and c of relation (2) are setting 1 in this table. Table 3.

In this section, we characterize the response of FGSW rectangular plate rested on Pasternak elastic foundation. The non-dimensional natural frequency and foundations stiffness are defined by: Ω=ωhρc/Ec, Kg=kgL12/Dc, Kw=kwL14/Dc, Dc=Ech3/12(1-vc2)

The influence of the index p on the natural frequency is shown in Figures 3 and 4. The new and interesting result is that although the value of natural frequency parameter is expected to be between the natural frequency parameter of the limit cases of homogeneous sheets of metal (p = 0) and of ceramic (p=∞), natural frequency parameter sometimes exceed the limit cases. It means though frequency parameter of the plate with ceramic rich sheets (p = ∞) is more than the plate with metal rich sheets (p = 0), the frequency parameter of the sandwich plate does not necessarily increase with the increase of ceramic volume fraction. Various parameters such as the power-law distribution profile, mechanical properties of materials, elastic foundations modulus, geometry of the plate, etc can influence on this fact. Thus, it is possible to obtain dynamic characteristics similar or better than the isotropic ceramic limit case for sheets of sandwich plate rested on Pasternak foundation by choosing suitable values of the three parameters b, c, p. The first normalized frequencies of different types of FGSW plates are compared with each other in Table 4 for different values of h/L1 ratio and hf/h ratio. In this table, the volume fraction profiles through thickness are classical for b = 0, symmetric for b = 1, c = 2 and asymmetric for b = 1, c = 4. It can be concluded from Table 4 that the normalized frequencies of symmetric profile are smaller than that of other types of FGSW plates for different values of p, hf/h ratio and h/L1 ratio. Also, it can be found, the normalized frequencies of classic profile are larger than that of other types of FGSW plates for different values of hf/h ratio and h/L1 ratio. Figure 3.
Variation of the first non-dimensional natural frequency of functionally graded sandwich (FGSW) square plate resting on elastic foundation vs. the power-law exponent p for various values of the parameter b (0≤b≤1,c=1,h/L1=0.4,hf/h=0.2,Kw=10,Kg=1).
Figure 4.
Variation of the first non-dimensional natural frequency of functionally graded sandwich (FGSW) square plate resting on elastic foundation vs. the power-law exponent p for various values of the parameter c (b=1,1≤c≤10,h/L1=0.4,hf/h=0.2,Kw=10,Kg=1).
Table 4.

Figure 5 shows the effect of Winkler elastic coefficient on the first non-dimensional natural frequency for different values of shearing layer elastic coefficients. The most effective range of Winkler foundation stiffness in increasing the non-dimensional natural frequency is from 102 to 104. It is also observed that for the large values of Winkler elastic coefficient, the shearing layer elastic coefficient has less effect and the results become independent of it. In other words, the non-dimensional natural frequencies converge with increasing Winkler foundation stiffness. The influence of shearing layer elastic coefficient on the first non-dimensional natural frequency is shown in Figure 6. The most effective range of shearing layer foundation stiffness in increasing the non-dimensional natural frequency is from 10 to 103. It shows that the variation of Winkler elastic coefficient has little effect on the non-dimensional natural frequency for kg > 103. Figure 5.
Variation of the first non-dimensional natural frequency of functionally graded sandwich (FGSW) square plate resting on elastic foundation vs. Winkler elastic coefficient for different shearing layer elastic coefficients (b=1,c=2,p=1,h/L1=0.4,hf/h=0.2).
Figure 6.
Variation of the first non-dimensional natural frequency of functionally graded sandwich (FGSW) square plate resting on elastic foundation vs. shearing layer elastic coefficients for different Winkler elastic coefficient (b=1,c=2,p=1,h/L1=0.4,hf/h=0.2).

The effect of length-to-width ratio of the FGSW plate on the first non-dimensional natural frequency is shown in Figure 7. It shows that the non-dimensional natural frequency decreases with the increase of L1/L2 ratio and then remains almost unaltered for L1/L2 greater than 5 at different values of Winkler and shearing layer elastic coefficients. Figure 7.
The effect of length to width ratio of the functionally graded sandwich (FGSW) plate (L1/L2) on the non-dimensional natural frequency (b=1,c=2,p=1,h/L1=0.5,hf/h=0.3).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
An accurate solution procedure based on the three-dimensional elasticity theory for the free vibration analysis of thick FG plates on two-parameter elastic foundation is presented. A three-parameter power-law distribution is considered for the variation of FG materials through thickness of plate. Since no assumptions on stresses and displacements have been employed, it can be applied to the free vibration analysis of plates with arbitrary thickness. Using the DQ method through the thickness of the plate further allows one to deal with FG plates with an arbitrary thickness distribution of material properties. The effects of different geometrical parameters such as the thickness-to-length ratio, the elastic foundation parameters, different profiles of fiber volume fraction and three parameters of power-law distribution on the vibration characteristics of the FGSW plates are investigated. The solution can be used as benchmark for other numerical methods and also the refined plate theories. From this study, some conclusions can be made:
Interesting result shows that by choosing suitable values of b, c and p, frequency parameter can be obtained more than the frequency parameter of the similar FGSW plate with sheets made of 100% ceramic and at the same time lighter. This result is against the expected one for the frequency parameter of FGSW plate to fall between those for p = 0 (100% metal) and p = ∞ (100% ceramic).
Results show that normalized frequencies of symmetric and classic profiles are smaller and larger than that of other types of FGSW plates, respectively, for different values of p, hf/h ratio and h/L1 ratio.
The most effective ranges of shearing layer elastic coefficient and Winkler foundation stiffness in increasing the non-dimensional natural frequencies is from 10 to 103and 102 to 104, respectively.
It is observed that for the large values of Winkler elastic coefficient, the shearing layer elastic coefficient has less effect on the normalized frequency and the results become independent of it.
It can be found that the normalized natural frequencies of FGSW plate increase with increasing hf/h ratio.
It results the non-dimensional natural frequency decreases with increasing L1/L2 ratio and then remain almost unaltered for L1/L2 greater than 5 at different values of Winkler and shearing layer elastic coefficients.
